data.text: For verily all men by nature Or, are  were but  vain who had no perception of God,
But either fire, or wind, or swift air,
And if it was through delight in their beauty that they took them to be gods,
But if it was through astonishment at their power and Gr. efficacy.  influence,
For from the Some authorities read greatness and beauty of.  greatness of the beauty Some authorities omit even.  even of created things
But yet for these Or, things  men there is but small blame,
For Or, being occupied with  living among his works they make diligent search,
But again even they are not to be excused.
For if they had power to know so much,
But miserable Or, are  were  they, and Or, amongst  in dead things Or, are  were  their hopes,
Yea and if some Gr. carpenter who is a woodcutter.  woodcutter, having sawn down a Gr. plant. The Greek word, slightly changed, would mean trunk  tree that is easily moved,
And burning the refuse of his handywork to dress his food, eateth his fill;
And taking the very refuse thereof which served to no use,
Or maketh it like some paltry animal,
And having made for it a chamber worthy of it,
While then he taketh thought for it that it may not fall down,
When he maketh his prayer concerning goods and his marriage and children,
Yea for health he calleth upon that which is weak,
And for gaining and Or, handywork  getting and good success of his hands
